1.cardOverview: Built from scratch to unify fragmented marketing operations across 4 departments, replacing manual Excel workflows with real-time data visibility. Grew from Mid UI Designer to co-owning product strategy and creating the company's first Design Ops team.

storyTeaser.cta: Read how I went from UI executor to co-owning product strategy

detailMetrics.label: QA cycles reduced through design systems

contentBlocks.quote: How did I get here? This definitely wasn't in the job description for Mid UI Designer.
contentBlocks.context: Seven months into my first corporate design role, I found myself standing in front of a room full of engineers, presenting a design system architecture I'd built from scratch.

contentBlocks.heading: From Manual Chaos to Unified Platform

before.label: The Reality I Walked Into
items: Marketing tracking everything via manual Excel sheets
6+ fragmented lead entry points (events, social, website, telesales)
Social media complaints not reaching Customer Care
No file naming systems, no Figma libraries
No systematic handoffs or QA system
Multiple dev languages with no standardisation

after.label: What We Built in 18 Months
items: Unified CRM across 4 departments
Automated Facebook-to-CRM complaint pipeline
400+ design tokens, 200+ components
Real-time data visibility replacing manual workflows
90% fewer QA cycles through design systems
Design Ops team created, 5 designers trained

blocks.text: Create a unified platform for all marketing data so we could understand spending effectiveness and support 50% projected customer growth.
That was it. No product manager. No established patterns. No component library to work from. Just me, a backend developer, and a two-week deadline for the first prototype.

items: Timeline: MVP in 18 months
Tech stack: JavaFX (zero prior experience)
No communication with Marketing dept initially
No clear MVP definition
No product manager, no UX department
Frontend developer +8 hours timezone away
Complex multi-source data integration

image.caption: The team: 1 Backend Lead, 1 Frontend (remote), 1 Mid UI Designer (me)

blocks.text: From day one, it was clear this wasn't a typical 'design the screens' project. The Backend Lead and I became de facto co-owners of the product, making strategic decisions together.

blocks.html: Product Strategy & MVP Scoping: Jointly evaluated technical feasibility vs user needs. Backend assessed data availability and API constraints. I validated user value with Marketing Lead. Consensus-based decision making on what went in/out of scope.

Why This Worked: Backend Lead had a direct line to the CEO. Rather than compete for access, I leveraged this relationship—ensuring our co-owned decisions had clear technical backing when presented upward.

image.caption: Decision framework: User needs → Marketing Lead | Feasibility → Backend Lead | Design approach → Me | Strategic buy-in → Backend + Me together

blocks.text: Given the CEO's limited availability (he cared about results, not journey), I built validation through peer relationships:

items: Marketing Lead: Domain expert and primary user—validated workflows, terminology, feature value
Backend Lead: Technical feasibility, data architecture alignment, strategic partnership
Frontend Developer: Async handoff validation, implementation feasibility
CEO: Results-based check-ins, strategic buy-in moments

contentBlocks.title: Strategic Decision: Design System First
contentBlocks.insight: Observed chaos across company projects and pitched a design system approach. CEO initially denied it. VP of Frontend tentatively approved. My response? Do it anyway and prove the value.
contentBlocks.result: By month 15, CEO approved design system expansion company-wide. Now serving multiple products with 400+ tokens and 200+ components.

left.heading: Key Win: Facebook API Approval (First Try)

blocks.text: When tackling social media integration, Backend researched API limitations while I designed ideal user flows. We'd meet to reconcile: 'Facebook requires X for approval, which means we need Y in the design.'

blocks.html: This back-and-forth happened before engineering started, saving weeks of rework.

blocks.text: Result: We got Facebook API approval first try—the design met their requirements because we'd built them in collaboratively from the start.

image.caption: Facebook integration flow designed with API constraints from day one

contentBlocks.heading: Key Win: The Feature I Invented
contentBlocks.text:
Through validation sessions with Marketing Lead, I uncovered a recurring pain point: Social Media Manager spent huge amounts of time dealing with customer complaints via Facebook messages, playing telephone between customers and Customer Care department.

My Proposal: FB-to-CRM Complaint Pipeline

1. Social Media Manager flags a conversation as 'Assistance Required'
2. Chatbot scans messages for keywords and account numbers
3. System automatically matches account to customer profile in CRM
4. Flagged conversation appears in Customer Care's dashboard
5. Customer Care handles complaint with full context

Cross-Team Impact:
• Social Media Manager: 30% inbox reduction, focus on actual social media work
• Customer Care: Centralised complaint tracking, automatic customer profile matching
• Business: Clear visibility into customer pain points, improved care perception
contentBlocks.caption: Automated complaint routing saving 30% of Social Media Manager's time

contentBlocks.title: Design System Adoption: Proving Value
contentBlocks.insight: I wanted to pitch design systems properly with presentations and buy-in meetings. CEO didn't care about process. So I built it, proved it worked through 90% QA reduction, and then got approval to scale it.
contentBlocks.result: Design system now serves multiple products. Design Ops team created. 5 designers trained in systems approach. Product showcased at developer conferences.

left.heading: What I Learned: Growing Into the Role

blocks.text: The strongest validation doesn't come from executives—it comes from the people you work with daily. Building deep collaboration with Backend made us both more effective. Learning to leverage his relationship with CEO rather than competing for access was strategic.

I wanted to pitch design systems properly, with presentations and buy-in meetings. CEO didn't care. So I built it, proved it worked, and then got approval to scale it. Sometimes you have to show, not tell.

+8 hour timezone difference and language barriers could have killed the project. Instead, we invented an annotation and prototype system that worked so well it reduced QA by 90%. The constraint forced us to communicate better than we would have otherwise.

Learning marketing terminology, workflows, and pain points made me a strategic partner, not just a service provider. I could propose features (like the FB-to-CRM pipeline) because I understood the problem space deeply.

Every component I built systematically saved hours later. Every token properly structured meant consistency without rework. The upfront investment in design systems paid off exponentially—and became the foundation for the entire company's design practice.
6. You Don't Need a Title to Lead

I was hired as Mid UI. I ended up co-owning product strategy, creating design infrastructure, presenting to engineers, and mentoring the team. Leadership isn't about job title—it's about stepping up when there's a gap and proving you can fill it.

items: More structured user validation earlier: Push harder for at least lightweight usability testing with 2-3 actual users per major feature release
Set clearer MVP boundaries upfront: The 'we'll figure it out' approach worked but caused stress. Next time I'd push for a written feature matrix in month 1
Document design decisions in real-time: Track more 'why' behind design choices for future me and future designers

Skills Demonstrated: Product: User research, IA, MVP scoping, strategic thinking
Design Systems: Token architecture, component dev, automation
Collaboration: Engineering partnership, async remote work, stakeholder management
Leadership: Leading without authority, culture change, mentorship, scaling practice
